text: What's the recommended way to build a large string across many calls? Given that Strings are immutable, I assume that standard concatenation using `*` will be inefficient.

text: It depends a bit. If it's occuring in a single line x = a * b * c, that is done all in one. But if you're doing a loop or something, yeah it's inefficient.

text: I suppose writing to an IOBuffer is how one would do it otherwise.

elements.text: I suppose writing to an IOBuffer is how one would do it otherwise.

text: `print` to an `IOBuffer` and then use `String(take!(buf))` once you are done writing to it

elements.text: once you are done writing to it

text:
TIL that string concat using `*` is slow! For anyone else following along, here's some simple benchmarks I did: On my machine, for N=100000 loop iterations, `*=` gives a 3.6s, `IOBuffer` gives a speedy 19.7 ms  (for N=100, only 19.0 us and 17.3 us)

```@btime let
    myStr = ""
    for i in 1:N
        myStr *= "_$i"
    end
    nothing
end

@btime let
    io = IOBuffer()
    for i in 1:N
        print(io, "_$i")
    end
    myStr = String(take!(io));
    nothing
end```

elements.text: is slow! For anyone else following along, here's some simple benchmarks I did: On my machine, for N=100000 loop iterations,

text: `print(io, "_", i)` should be slightly faster still, since it avoids allocating an intermediate string.

elements.text: should be slightly faster still, since it avoids allocating an intermediate string.

text:
Wow! TIL some more! It was actually even faster than I thought it would be. Here it is below.
N = 100000
3500 ms for `*=`
19.2 ms for `print(io, "_$i")`,
14.0 ms for `print(io, "_", i)`

text:
```N = 100000
  3.462 s (699489 allocations: 26.99 GiB) [using *= ]
  19.193 ms (599508 allocations: 26.93 MiB) [using print(io, "_$i") ]
  14.016 ms (399508 allocations: 14.73 MiB) [using print(io, "_", i)]```

text: What happens if you used `write` instead of `print` ?
:open_mouth:
`print(io::IO, s::Union{String,SubString{String}}) = (write(io, s); nothing)`
<https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/blob/master/base/strings/io.jl#L194>
Super fast.
`write(io, ::Int)` likely won't do what you'd expect

text:
```begin
           io = IOBuffer()
           for i in 1:3
               write(io, "_", i)
           end
           myStr = String(take!(io))
           end
"_\x01\0\0\0\0\0\0\0_\x02\0\0\0\0\0\0\0_\x03\0\0\0\0\0\0\0"```

elements.text:
begin
           io = IOBuffer()

text: Though `write` was really fast though
on the order of 3ms compared to 14ms compared to print (for N = 100000)

elements.text: on the order of 3ms compared to 14ms compared to print (for N = 100000)

text:
```julia> begin
                  io = IOBuffer()
                  for i in 1:3
                      write(io, "_", '0' + i)
                  end
                  myStr = String(take!(io))
                  end
"_1_2_3"```
